commentBody:
My five favorite clues from last week 
(in order of appearance):

1. Felt something on your head?  (6)
2. Having a strong sense of direction?  (5)
3. It's cool while it's hot  (3)
4. Provided entrees  (6)(5)
5. Handled press agents  (5)


FEDORA
BOSSY
FAD
OPENED DOORS
IRONS
Some extremely quick Monday fun.
This was fun. I enjoyed the theme. Thanks, Kevin & Andrea. Have a great Monday, y‚Äôall!

A fast solve for me as well, but fun and clever.

Perfect for a Monday puzzle.
65D, the one in my window should have been put away a month ago. Now I‚Äôm really feeling the heat.

Two pros produce an easy but pleasing puzzle, just the thing  for a Monday. I do hope at least one component of the proper noun crosses will be known to everyone, to  keep them out of that town on the Boston marathon.

(23Ax11D, 24Ax18D, 46Ax39D, 52Ax52D+54D) 

Thanks, Kevin and  ACME

Isaac, you write:
73A. The [Aussie critters] here are ROOS. There‚Äôs not an obvious point in the clue that would denote the shortened term, so I needed a crosser to figure this one out.

Aussie is a shortened form. That denotes a shortened form, plus critters is slang, for lack of a better word, indicating a nickname would be involved.
No stress test today, just a fun puzzle, elegantly simple.  Kevin and Andrea Carla, thank you for this Monday gem.  Looking forward to seeing you again LATER!

"I always like to work backward from the revealer..." as Isaac  offers in Today's Theme, is a good strategy if you want to solve a puzzle as quickly as possible. I solve to savor the puzzle, not for speed, so I try to guess the revealer as I fill in the theme answers. It's your puzzle; solve it as you wish.

So points for above average amount of theme material for a Monday, and smooth fill. Not a very tight theme though and nothing particularly enjoyable in the solve or clues. So call it a very workmanlike Monday that gets the job done.
Thank you, Andrea and Kevin, for a smooth & fun Monday solve - a wonderful way to begin the week! I enjoyed the cluing for the AC theme as it unfolded - hope we'll see more from the two of you!‚ò∫Ô∏è
A lovely clean sweep and satisfying Monday puzzle‚Ä¶kudos to the creators and to NYT for publication! Happy Monday ü¶ãüëèü•≥
Awesomely clever!
I thought ORCAs were dolphins, not whales... no?
I watched Lassie for years (with Jeff, Lassie's true owner) and Lassie don' need no stinkin' leash!
Slang for a huge fan?  Stan?

"My A/C is better than yours!"
"Stop putting on airs!"

("Sorry if I'm cooler.")

when i niggle late week i am often chided here with the injunction:  the later in the week the bendier the clues.
so today i will pick the nit that while a cranium is part of a skull it is not synonymous with a skull, as the skull includes the bones of the face and the jaw.
which the cranium does not.
now...is monday too late in the week to quibble?

Speaking of Aussie critters‚Ä¶ I‚Äôm happy to report that mine is doing much better. He was struggling with severe back pain for a while, but a month of electromagnetic sessions with the Assisi Loop have pretty much returned him to normal. These days, he‚Äôs a much happier (and bouncier) Roo. Thanks to everyone who asked and gave support. And of course, thanks to the puzzle creators for another welcome shoutout!

The clue for 72 across is so clever and it was fun to solve. Kudos.

Re the Aussie critters--the abbreviation indicator in the clue is the word "Aussie."
Critter?  I would have thought it was a bit too large to be called a critter‚Ä¶
I hope they went for a double header and tomorrow's grid will be DC themed.
Aww, this was Actually Cute for a Monday. Thank you, Kevin and Andrea, for this Adorably Charming grid üòç

Yes, I feel I've been doing this crossword long enough now to be confident of saying, "Very Monday-ish".

I did get a bit stuck on LOCAL, it not being a term I use for trains. I don't use express either really. It's fast train or slow/stopping train, although I once asked a train guard if the next train was 'the fast one' and he said, "They all travel at the same speed .... "

I didn't realise there was a revealer until almost the very end; I had ignored the clue because I thought it would be an unknown US cold drink. Then I couldn't think what an AC could be. Air conditioning is rare here, it didn't spring to mind at first.

All in all, very satisfactory.
I've been 100% focused on the campaign (yeah, that's me ringing your doorbell) so waaaaay behind on the solving but this was a nice break.  I'll save Saturday's for tomorrow.
Mauvelous! Siriously!!
As much as I love Andrea's work, I thought this one to be ridiculously easy, even for a Monday.

Fun Monday puzzle - in the vicinity of dad jokes so right up my alley. Just a bit on the slow side, as it took me a bit to tumble to the trick, but that was just a nice 'aha' moment. A couple of fun puzzle finds today. The first one a Wednesday from May 16, 2018 by Jonathan Schmalzbach and Bill Albright. The theme clues and answers: "Nickname for a glitzy author?" JEWELSVERNE "Nickname for a clumsy composer?" CLODDEBUSSY "Nickname for a sloppy painter?" TOOLOOSELAUTREC "Nickname for a fiery philosopher?" BLAZEPASCAL And the reveal was: "Classic hairstyle ... or a hint to the puns in 17-, 25-, 39- and 51-Across" FRENCHTWIST Here's that Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=5/16/2018&g=46&d=A I'll put my other puzzle find in a reply. ...
A crossword.

Apt Collaboration of two Amazing Constructors produced Awesome Crossword.

(I even solved it Ante-Caffeine.)
axe MAN?! Give me a break.
Nice to be back to regularly scheduled pleasant Monday crosswords after last week

Nice one Kevin and.. my dove.

Thank you both!

Better Call S___, 34A and 40A all appearing in the same grid? Was that a coincidence? Is Slippin‚Äô Jimmy not the quintessential 40A, or what? Incidentally, my favorite guest appearance is Mark Proksch‚Äôs ‚ÄúPryce‚Äù character who debuted in the episode ‚ÄúPimento.‚Äù The whole scene is hilarious. From his Wisconsin drawl being so out of place (for the southwest) up to and concluding with Hoboken squat cobbler. Simply classic. Today I decided to refrain from using the ‚ÄúG‚Äù word (4D). I‚Äôve never been referred to as either, and I‚Äôm still wallowing in self-pity over the little hatchet men robbing us of our precious capos. Then, being force-fed treble knobs‚Ä¶ it‚Äôs just deplorable. You‚Äôll find these two links entertaining, especially the second one. https://leftyfretz.com/why-is-guitar-called-axe/ https://leftyfretz.com/forbidden-riffs/
An amazing piece of crossword construction on a simple Monday solve. Thank you.
Had YUCA instead of YUMA (never heard of it) and had to check what I had wrong. A bit naticky there, but otherwise a swift puzzle.
Hi solvers, you may have noticed some technical issues with our website this morning. Our team has swiftly resolved them and you should be able to get back to your games.

11:34 solving time. 4m faster than my avg. 

im impressed by how unusually difficult for a monday this seemed at the start, and how everything fell into place like an abstract painting, ending up being a faster than usual monday solve. i think i was done in four, successively shorter, passes.

C.

Not much to say about a Monday puzzle, but I did appreciate the samovar in the column photo, as samovar is one of my favorite words. It ranks right up there with imaret and thurible.

Whew, good thing we had a revealer, or I would have been All Confused.

Fun one: 12D make me laugh! As did the mental image pairing the action of [tree frogs] and [ballerinas]. 

28D had me smiling about our resident quahog, for sure. Such a funny phrase, but a good reminder of a certain type of contentment when I tend to be full of the jitters these days. 

I thought maybe we were headed for a pangram, but alas no F, G(!) or Z. 

Thanks, Andrea and Kevin! Now I have the All Clear to start my day (and my week!).
That was easy and fun, perfect for a Monday puzzle!

Caviar and mackerel
Likes to swim au naturel
A dolphin but not nice

She's a killer whale
Oreo black, Oreo pale
Doesn't need no stinkin scales
Some folks claim she's ill-defined
Every time

This felt pretty easy for me (as it should on a Monday), but not "too easy," as some seem to suggest. I've been doing the NYT Crossword for long enough that in order to have even the slightest chance at a personal best, I need to be 95% accurate on the first pass through the horizontal clues. I wasn't close to that, but everything came together very satisfyingly on the verticals. Fun Monday!

Message for Mr Fagliano:
The clue for 4 down in today's mini is based on several myths. First: the "seven" story goes back to an academic article by George Miller in the 1950s, titled "The Magic Number Seven--plus or minus two". It noted that most people could repeat betweenn 5 and 9 random digits read to them rapidly. Later research showed that this is a function of the "phonological loop," a section of the mind's language-processing capabities that keeps the most recent 2 seconds or so of heard speech in the forefront of memory. 
As a result, Chinese has a "magic number" of 9, plus or minus 2, because Chinese digits can be spoken very rapidly. For Welsh, the number is 6.
That phone numbers have 7 digits is utterly unrelated to this. First, they haven't always had 7--and with an area code required in overlay areas, they have 10 nowadays.

In other countries, the number of digits is variable! My folks in Germany had a 5-digit number with a 4-digit area code. My sister lives in a big city with a 2-digit area code. Her phone number has 6 digits; the fax number, 8. 

So, ultimately the "magic number 7" story boils down to what one retains from the most recent 2 seconds of speech--and nothing else.

One more late puzzle find. This one was all in the clues - a Sunday from September 8, 2019 by Joe DiPietro with the title: "Well, well, well, if it isn't..." This one was all in the clues. Some examples: "... the guy who vows to take his Stetson to the grave" BURYTHEHATCHET "... the fraternity guy who wants to be a cardiologist" HEARTBROKEN "... the guy who barely shows he's exasperated" SHORTSIGHTED "... the gal who delivered the greatest put-down ever" WHATADISGRACE "... the gal who loses it when pass plays are called" GROUNDNUTMEG "... the guy who can't stop bragging about Bragg" FORTLAUDERDALE And there were more. Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=9/8/2019&g=73&d=D ...
I missed the revealer since 65D had long since been filled in, but I should have been curious about the clues marked with asterisks. I guess I was tired and wanted to hurry to bed.

Any puzzle with CLAM in it is perfectly crumulent with me, as long as there is no mention of chowder... 

I was expecting the usual kefuffle re: ORCA and was not disappointed. The misconception that ORCAs are not whales comes up every time an ORCA is correctly clued as a whale. 

I was also expecting the misconception that the end of the clue for 28D would be "at high tide" because that is when we are spared predation. No! All sorts of nasty predators come up from the sea and are actively hunting us at high tide. Crabs, fishes, and so on. We are happy at high tide because we get to be active then -- for example, we get to eat! During low tide, we have to, well, CLAM up. We cannot feed, we are subjected to thermal (and sometimes salinity) stress, we often have to go anaerobic, and so on. We get to recover from all that stress when the mother ocean comes to cover us again. And that recovery takes energy, so we have to feed! Glorious, succulent phytoplankton! MMMmmMMMmmm! Soup's on!

Augustus Caesar because of I, Claudius and that wonderful adaptation shown in the US on PBS in the 1970s.

But being from the Bay Area, also the tragedy of Allen Cedric.
Art Fleming! Thank you.
"ROOS" was obvious to me ~ Kanga ROOS!
This exact theme was done fairly recently, wasn‚Äôt it??
One of the cleanest grids I've seen!  Nice work.  Perfect Monday.
Can we please move on from misogynistic notions about guitarists being men??

New personal best*, breaking a barrier that I struggle to break! And that's solving most of the puzzle at work, on my lunch break, on my phone--I left the 40A and 65D blank, to be filled in once I got home. It can do much more than go "Oom-pah"!: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7ts23tALni4&list=RD7ts23tALni4&start_radio=1 https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AY30Eya0PGg&list=RDAY30Eya0PGg&start_radio=1 *or so I believe--some of the times on my "stats" page are completely whackadoodle! Stats says I completed Saturday, Nov. 23, 2024, thirty seconds fast than today. Yeah, right!

The assertion that the word "news" comes from the 4 major directions of the compass is often repeated, but is spurious. The word actually comes from the word new. The idea that it came from the 4 directions was first told in jest with the earliest examples apparently back in the 1600s.

One more puzzle. Can't remember if I ever mentioned this one before. I'll re-post this tomorrow. Anyway - a Sunday from August 7, 2022 by Tina Labadie with the title "Letterplay." All the theme answers in this one were two of them paired together with one referencing the other. One example: 54a "Weightlessness ... or a hint to 118-Across" ZEROG 118a. "Baseball announcer's call on a home run" OINOINONE And another example: 90a. "Club for farm kids ... or a hint to 97-Across" FOURH 97a. "Secretive" HUSHHUSH And one more. 68a: "Top credit rating ... or a hint to 25-Across" TRIPLEA 25a: "Not true?" ATANANGLE And there were more. Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=8/7/2022&g=80&d=D ....
Clean as a whistle...great Monday puzzle!
Liked the cross of STAN and TREX as STAN is the name of a TREX fossil found in South Dakota in the late 80s.

My five favorite encore clues from last week:

[Mythical luster?]  (5)
[Small dessert sandwiches]  (5)


SATYR
OREOS

especially now:

"People ask me what I do in winter when there's no baseball. I'll tell you what I do. I stare out the window and wait for spring.‚Äù
          - Rogers Hornsby

YEAH, we had a first frost last night; DHubby helped me trundle the lemon tree into the garage just in the knick of time...(although, just for fun, I call it "the KINK of time."  ...which goes double on this Monday...

I agree with your comment so much that I won't be writing my own.

Please find your whimsy‚Ä¶
 He was just adding his own AC.  
Actually Charming of him!

@Andrea Carla Michaels

Apt comment, thank you! I only now noticed Joe used the theme you created. I'm such a loser in this thread ü§£

Actually comical!

And I'm reduced to being an aching curmudgeon. 

(It was a very fine and relaxing Monday - exactly because you did not overcomplicate it in an awsomely clever way)
@Joe. It was straightforward. But fitting in 7 long and good theme answers is impressive, imo.
Round and round we go... "The orca, or killer whale, is a toothed whale and the largest member of the oceanic dolphin family." https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Orca
@Michael they are dolphins; that tripped me up.
@Michael as a minimum the NYT should choose what they clue. We‚Äôve had the clue ‚Äúmembers of the dolphin family that preys on dolphins‚Äù  ‚Äî or words to that effect ‚Äî solving to ORCA.
@Barry Ancona So an orca is a dolphin and a dolphin is a kind of whale?

@Ms. Billie M. Spaight
Yes, all dolphins are whales, toothed whales specifically.
@Barry Ancona ok, I'm looking forward to the next cluing of HUMAN as "Old World Monkey." It should be done, if it hasn't! https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Catarrhini
@Michael Regardless they are surely large-toothed and not large toothed whales, being rather diminutive for the category.
@Michael Well we did have GREAT APES clued to Humans (and gorillas and chimpanzees) just a few days ago! üòÇ See 14A: https://www.nytimes.com/crosswords/game/daily/2025/10/31
Four letters with any reference to marine mammal always assume ORCA.  Its the OREO of the sea.

Now that we've settled the whale/dolphin controversy, can we return to the unending OCTOP*** question?
And why is it always sea creatures that give us grief? You'll notice we're hardly bothered by spiders and marmosets, and even deer snd sheep seem well-settled. Buf just dip a toe in the drink and the fish/fishes leap out to harass us.

@SBK
Sorry for repeated posts. I don't know why this is happening. ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è

@John - Considering that ALL dolphins are whales, then an ORCA would most certainly be on the large end of the toothed-whale spectrum. They are not small animals. 

An ORCA  is about the same length as, say, a minke whale, but much more robust, so much heavier (larger) than a minke. A large ORCA would be about half the length of the largest toothed whale -- the sperm whale. They are not small animals.
@John They are the second-largest toothed whale. Only the sperm whale is larger.

@SBK

Whatever you do, do NOT mention four-legged ELKS!!!

@SBK

CLAMs make no trouble--they're famously happy, right Cap'n Q?

@Mtmetz - Well... we are, supposedly at high tide! 

See my lengthy-ish comment elsewhere...

And you know that leash would just caught on something while Lassie was running through the woods, and then who would tell everyone that Timmy‚Äôs in the well??

@Matt cranium is the latin word for skull and the official anatomical term for the part of the skull that isn't the face/jaw is the neurocranium (i.e. braincase) so I think this clue is fair enough
@OsteoSynth https://www.google.com/search?q=ren+snd+stimpy+no+sir+i+dont+like+it&rlz=1CDGOYI_enIL1137IL1137&hl=en-US&sourceid=chrome-mobile&ie=UTF-8#fpstate=ive&vld=cid:8d1bc395,vid:8JNuqEz_GCQ,st:0

@Matt

These are *clues*--not definitions.  Thus exactitude is not required.  Especially not on a Monday, and this Monday in particular.  
You are of course correct, except that this is a crossword puzzle, not an exam, so lenience is expected.  
Possibly this puzzle was chosen because most citizens are dealing with the Time Change that creates havoc semi-annually...  For example, our cat is not on board with the time alteration, and she was beside herself at 5 a.m. when I didn't get up and check the food bowl....
@Matt Honestly I‚Äôve learned that no matter what someone will comment to be contrarian here. These are NYT Crossword devotees and they won‚Äôt have their precious subscription go to waste ü§£

You don't?!

@Steve L

@Steve L
One of the words for insect in Yiddish is "BRU-yim". I was in my 20s before I realized that it was, in fact, the Hebrew word "bru-IM", lit., things which have been created, AKA creatures.

@RF. Someone already did a DC COMICS it was super fun DANA CARVEY ‚Ä¶I can‚Äôt remember who all else, but it was clever! And KEVIN and I did an AC/DC two years ago‚Ä¶ those letters appeared (together, in order) in each theme phrase https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=1/9/2023

Jane,

The terms "local" and "express" have always been used on all levels of U.S. rail passenger transport, not just on the NYC Subway.
N.B. Also "local" and "limited" (limited stops), used in rail and road (bus) operation.

@Steve L
I wasn't thinking of underground trains, they are all the same, just what we call mainline trains. The big ones, like the Flying Scotsman (in the old version of The 39 Steps) that used to go choo-choo, puff-puff. I still love a steam train,
@Barry Ancona And Jane said that SHE didn‚Äôt use those terms. Your point is moot, and once again you‚Äôre just pinching down on people.

D,
You're having trouble following this thread...

"I wasn't thinking of underground trains, they are all the same, just what we call mainline trains."

Jane,
As I assumed! Over here, on the New York Central, we had the Empire State Express and  the 20th Century Limited ... and locals that made all the stops.

@Jane Wheelaghan
Not only there. The Flying Scotsman has an entire literary life. I'm having a British mystery interval and it's in Michael Gilbert's great Petrella mystery Blood and Judgment. (Seasonally appropriate, I just realised, as it's set on Guy Fawkes  Day.)

@Barry Ancona
I love trains having names. When my father came home from Europe at the end of WW2 he was on the London-Edinburgh Union of South Africa. We saw it together when it had a 'visit' to Edinburgh many years later.
"Local" might be unfamiliar to solvers. In these parts there's just the normal (eg 20 Noodle) bus/trolley and express (eg 110 Noodle Express), which skips many stops.

@John Carson Good for you! People who go ringing doorbells are the best people to talk to, regardless of politics. My husband and I are on a 6  week trip and were so glad to get our mail-in ballots two days before we left.

@John Carson
Ugh. All of our network TV comes from across the river (there's no TV station in DE) and we've been bombarded with Jack vs Mikey ads.

@Grant

The tragedy of our current situation is that people will form opinions and make voting decisions based on that drivel - and I mean from all sides.

@John Carson
Great! I've been among the door-ringers (in Winnipeg winters -- no joke!) and you should know how indispensable and worthwhile that is. You never know when an election will come down to a mere handful of votes.

@John Carson
You seem like a well-centered guy, so please take this for what it‚Äôs worth. I‚Äôve spent considerable time in NJ, love the shoreline and its history.
  To quote a recent post: ‚ÄúMost of us are here to take a break from the real world.‚Äù As always, I remain curious what the ‚Äòtragedy of our current situation‚Äô actually means. 
I applaud you for what you're doing, but what's the goal of door-door campaigning? 
  Also, the myriad of election signs; do they actually have any effect on the outcome of an election? To me, they‚Äôre an eyesore and do nothing for me.
  Would a typical voter cast a ballot based on sign count? To me, the signs on someone‚Äôs lawn are merely a ‚ÄúGee, I‚Äôm a (fill in the party) supporter, so there.‚Äù I never look at a flyer or sign and think, ‚ÄúYa know, good point. I‚Äôm voting (party).‚Äù
Since I strive for a ‚Äúp‚Äùword-free safe(?) area. I‚Äôm just curious, that‚Äôs all.
May the outcome be in your favor, in reward for all your hard work. üá∫üá∏

@John Carson
Just don't be like those folks in Philly last year, who went knocking on doors when people were trying to watch the Eagles game.

@Grant

Ha!   We train specifically on that point.

@Steve L

I know what you mean, but even though I enjoy Thursday-Saturday puzzles the most, there is almost nothing I hate more than a hard Monday. It's the day for an easy, relaxing win. It's also a gateway for new solvers. It should be as simple as possible.

@Steve L

And I thought this one had some nice clueing, which I caught even as I whizzed by. Just right for a Monday, which of course is to be expected by these excellent constructors!

@Andrzej

I agree, generally, but  I thought this one was just too easy.  Of course, international solvers hit snags that are gimmes for most Americans.

Some potential examples:

ART Fleming
ELI Whitney
MRS Doubtfire, Fields and Maisel (movie, cookie, TV show)
YUMA, Arizona
WANDA Sykes
LEAH Remini

I figure some of the other American cultural items might be more widely known across the seas:  STAN, JAWS, AL CAPONE, etc.

Naturally, some Americans wouldn't know some of the first group, and the second group might not have reached some international solvers.

But, keeping in mind that the puzzle is pitched toward American solvers, and that constructors can only consider what most potential American solvers could reasonably be expected to know, most of this trivia should be gimmes for US NYT readers.  

And for crying out loud, the puzzle begins with [Fizzy pop] for SODA and [Eve's mate] for ADAM. That's like [Meowing pet] for CAT!

My time on this one was on the fast side, but not super fast, but mostly because my typing has slowed down a bit.  I was literally answering as fast as my fingers allowed me to.

Of course, your mileage may vary, as the great philosopher says.
@Steve L It‚Äôs Monday, the day for newcomers to enter into the hobby. As many people tell me on Thursdays, if you don‚Äôt like it then don‚Äôt play it and hit the archives.

@Steve L
Agreed, ACM's talent was wasted on this pedestrian puzzle.

@D

I generally like every day‚Äôs puzzles. My comment reflected my feelings about this particular puzzle. There no way to know how you‚Äôre going to feel about a particular puzzle until you do it.

@Rich in Atlanta And my other puzzle find - one of the strangest I have ever encountered. A Sunday from January 5, 1986 by Julian Ochrymowych with the title: "Janus Style." Some theme clue and answer examples (with an explanation on the first couple): "DIAPER" SILKFABRICDESRUBMIER Divide that in two and read the second half in reverse and that's SILKFABRIC and REIMBURSED. And when you reverse the clue, that becomes REPAID. "REWARD" RECOMPENSEREHCTEKS Second half of that one in reverse becomes "SKETCHER" And the reversed clue becomes DRAWER And here's one more - good luck figuring this one out; Clue: STINKER Answer: TWERPNIAGAYLMRIFSKNIL A couple of others: Clue: "PARTS" Answer: ACTORSLINESTCIRTSNOC Clue: "LAMINA" Answer: THINSCALEERUTAERC Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/PS?date=1/5/1986&g=26&d=A ....

@JohnWM
A comment.

SBK,

A? (Canadian)

@Linda Jo

Accolades Continue!

@Linda Jo
Very cute üòö

@Grant
Wonderful!

@Sally

The word NEWS is indeed made up "of" the four main compass points; it was not made up "from" them.

@Barry Ancona - The etymology sources I checked do not suggest that the word was made up of them, but rather from the word newes, meaning new things from long ago. Some sources also state that the name being derived to indicate the four compass points is not true.

Michael,
NEWS is "made up of" four letters that happen  to be the four main compass points; it was not "made up from" the four points.

G,
